thread.title: Theater Review: Angriest of '12 Jurors' dominates Barre Players' production
thread.title_full: Theater Review: Angriest of '12 Jurors' dominates Barre Players' production

author: Paul Kolas Telegram & Gazette Reviewer
title: Theater Review: Angriest of '12 Jurors' dominates Barre Players' production
text:
Theater Review: Angriest of '12 Jurors' dominates Barre Players' production Comment Posted Oct. 17, 2015 at 2:13 PM Updated Oct 17, 2015 at 3:58 PM By Paul Kolas Posted Oct. 17, 2015 at 2:13 PM Updated Oct 17, 2015 at 3:58 PM 'Twelve Angry Jurors' Two and a half stars
By Reginald Rose, directed by Robert Hawkins. At Barre Players Theater, 64 Common St., Barre. Performances Friday and Saturday at 7:30 p.m., Sunday at 2 p.m., through Oct... » Read more 'Twelve Angry Jurors' Two and a half stars
By Reginald Rose, directed by Robert Hawkins. At Barre Players Theater, 64 Common St., Barre. Performances Friday and Saturday at 7:30 p.m., Sunday at 2 p.m., through Oct. 25. Tickets: $14 general admission; seniors 65+ and students $12; children 12 and under $7. For reservations call (978) 355-2096 or (800) 733-2096, or visit www.barreplayerstheater.com 
With Colleen Kelley Norton, Mary LePage, Kristen King, Dave Piperno, Cindy Graber, Sandy Crompton, Hannah Hall, Matt Lee, Nancy Anderson, Emily Grandone, Ben Gawlik and Chelsey Patriss BARRE - A more apt title for Barre Players’ production of Reginald Rose’s “Twelve Angry Jurors” would be “One Extremely Angry Juror, Ten Irritated Jurors and One Skeptical Juror.” An updated adaptation of Rose’s 1954 teleplay, “Twelve Angry Men,” and the highly regarded 1957 film that followed, it’s a dramatic examination of the judicial system, and the tensions that flare up in the jury room when a unanimous vote of guilty or not guilty is needed to reach a verdict. By far the most volatile tension in director Robert Hawkins’ generally well-acted, but sometimes curiously interpreted staging, is supplied by Kristen King’s incendiary performance as Juror 3. King dominates the show with his towering presence and unchained emotion. He’s obdurately convinced that the 19-year-old boy on trial for stabbing his father to death is guilty beyond a reasonable doubt. So are 10 other jurors. The lone holdout is Juror 8 (Matt Lee), a mild-mannered architect who has his doubts, and spends the entire duration of the play trying to convince his fellow jurors that the so called “facts” of the evidence just don’t add up, and therefore cause for reasonable doubt. The cast of 12 are merely numbers with varied personalities. Juror 4 (Dave Piperno) is allied with Juror 3, but handles himself in a more civil, officious manner, claiming that the reason he feels the boy’s alibi is shaky – he was at a movie with his friends – is because he can’t remember the name of the movie. Most everyone wants to rush things along because they have better things to do. Juror 12 (Chelsey Patriss) is an ad agent who’s worried she’ll lose her job because of jury duty. Juror 9 (Nancy Anderson) is a compassionate teacher who is swayed by Juror 8 to change her vote to not guilty. That’s the only spoiler you’re going to get, but it’s hardly a big reveal in the eventual outcome. As Juror 8 indefatigably makes a strong case for reasonable doubt, second thoughts emerge, recede and re-emerge among the jurors. Some jurors are more open-minded than others. Juror 5 (Cindy Graber) knows what it’s like to grow up in a slum and empathizes with the boy’s rough upbringing. Juror 11 (Ben Gawlik) is a thoughtful immigrant who questions the logic of the boy running from the scene of the crime before wiping his fingerprints, then returning three hours later to remove the knife from his father’s chest. The youngest of the group, Juror 2 (Mary LePage), observantly questions how the boy, who is 5 feet 8 inches tall, could inflict a downward stab with a knife on his 6-foot-2-inch father. When a demonstration proves the possibility, Juror 5 shows everyone the proper way to hold a switchblade in a slum knife fight, and that a shorter person would thrust upward into a taller victim. Juror 6 (Sandy Crompton) has doubts about an elderly witness’s testimony that he heard a body fall to the floor, and ran to the door of his apartment in 15 seconds to see the boy running from his building. The man is a stroke victim and can’t possibly have made it to his door in 15 seconds. Even when Juror 8 demonstrates in the jury room that it would have taken him 42 seconds to make it to his door, Juror 3 remains vehemently unconvinced. Gum-chewing Juror 7 (Hannah Hall) is the most seemingly frivolous of the jury, more bored than truly invested in deciding the fate of a young boy’s life, and anxious to just get it over with. And even though we don’t know the ethnicity of the boy, Juror 10 (Emily Grandone) erupts into a disturbingly bigoted tirade about how everyone in the slums can’t be trusted, how “they” are all violent animals. It’s so full of hateful invective that it makes everyone disgustedly walk away from her. It’s King who reigns over this jury room with a performance of bludgeoning conviction, screaming “he’s got to burn!” When Juror 8 accuses him of being a sadist, more interested in fulfilling personal desire than rationally examining the facts, the two nearly come to blows averted by several others pulling No. 3 away from No. 8. Lee is quite good as No. 8, persuasively offering his arguments to reconsider a knee-jerk, let’s-get-it-over-with verdict. Colleen Kelley Norton quietly enacts the peacekeeping, role of Juror 1, diplomatically trying to forge unanimity with her fellow jurors. Other standouts in the capable ensemble include Gawlik’s Juror 11, portrayed with a nicely intoned Eastern European accent; Grandone’s eye-rolling bigoted Juror 10, although she needs to work on steadying her Southern accent; and Hall’s insouciant Juror 7. What comes into question is Hawkins’ sometimes seemingly arbitrary directorial and blocking choices, as when Juror 10 (Grandone) wanders off into the stage left bathroom (why is there a bathroom to begin with?) and takes a swig out of a bottle. Also worth argument is having a juror occasionally step forth from the others to deliver a private, spotlight-illuminated conversation with the audience. It’s a surreal touch that only serves to momentarily dispel the realistic tone of the play. On the whole, though, the verdict is not guilty. Looking for a self motivated, hard working, and versatile individual, wanting to perform all aspects of the MEP trades. Skills/Qualifications:Owns own tools - Vehicle SPECIAL REQUIREMENT: Must live in a designated HUBZone. Before submitting application, please check your address at http://map.sba.gov/hubzone/maps/ to confirm you meet this qualification. Please send resume to: smartllc@smartconstructioncorp.com [+] COORDINATOR, EMERGENCY STABILIZATION PROGRAM The COORDINATOR, EMERGENCY STABILIZATION PROGRAM The Emergency Stabilization/Homeless Prevention Program of Catholic Charities Worcester County is accepting resumes for tyhe position of Coordinator, Emergency Stabilization Program. This position oversees the provision of services to clients who are at risk of homelessness and hunger and in need of basic assistance. The position provides direct services to clients, case management and staff supervision. Hours are 37.5/week, Monday-Friday. A bachelor's degree in Human Service or a related field, with at least one year of supervisory experience is preferred. Interested candidates should send a resume and cover letter to: HRM, 10 Hammond St, Worcester, MA 01610 AA/EOE [+] CASE MANAGER POSITIONS - FULL TIME Montachusett CASE MANAGER POSITIONS - FULL TIME Montachusett Home Care Corp., a growing full social service agency serving elderly and the disabled has openings for full-time Case Managers in its State Home Care programs: A Bachelor's degree in Human Services or related field is required plus one year experience in casework. Eligibility for social work licensure is preferred. MHCC offers a friendly work environment, flexible work schedules, generous vacation, sick & holidays. Benefits include health, disability & life insurance, 403B matching, flexible spending etc. Older workers, minorities, and Spanish speaking individuals are encouraged to apply. A driver's license along with a fully registered and insured automobile is required. Computer experience is necessary. Send resume to: Montachusett Home Care Corporation Human Resources Department 680 Mechanic St., Leominster, MA 01453 Or via e-mail: mhcc@mhcc-1.org AA/EOE [+] RESIDENTIAL STAFF/HUMAN SERVICES Youville House RESIDENTIAL STAFF/HUMAN SERVICES Youville House Shelter for Families, a program of Catholics Charities Worcester county, is accepting resumes for Residential Staff, to work a variety of shifts. Experience working with homelessness or in a Human Service environment is preferred. Interested candidates should send a resume and cover letter to HRM, 10 Hammond St, Worcester, MA 01601. AA/EOE [+] NURSING POSITIONS - PART-TIME Montachusett Home NURSING POSITIONS - PART-TIME Montachusett Home Care Corporation, a social service agency serving both disabled and elderly population has openings for part-time RN positions in the Personal Care Attendant Program. Experience working with disabled consumers in the community is preferred. Position involves completing in-home assessments of need and confirming program eligibility. RN candidates should have at least 2 years experience in community nursing or 1-2 years of inpatient experience with the disabled population. Massachusetts RN and Motor Vehicle licenses are required. A fully registered and insured automobile is a must. Working knowledge of computers is necessary. Part time hours will be either 2 full work days or 2.5 work days each week. Enjoy nights, weekends, and holidays with your family. Older workers, minorities, and Spanish speaking individuals are encouraged to apply. Send resume by October 16, 2015 to: Montachusett Home Care Corporation Crossroads Office Park 680 Mechanic St., Leominster, MA 01453 Or via e-mail: mhcc@mhcc-1.org AA/EOE [+] HOME
